title: 109_s183
content: The Act may be cited as the "Family Opportunity Act of 2005" or the "Dylan Lee James Act." It includes amendments to the Social Security Act and provides a table of contents for the Act. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2005" or the "Dylan Lee James Act" includes provisions for families of disabled children to purchase Medicaid coverage for such children. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2005" allows families of disabled children to buy Medicaid coverage for them. This amendment includes adding a new subclause for disabled children under 19 years old. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2005" allows families to buy Medicaid coverage for disabled children under 19 years old who meet specific criteria related to age, disability status, and family income levels. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2005" allows families to buy Medicaid coverage for disabled children under 19 years old based on specific income criteria set by the State, not exceeding 300 percent of the poverty line for a family of the size involved. Any medical assistance for individuals exceeding this income limit must be funded by the State, with no Federal financial participation provided. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2005" allows families to purchase Medicaid coverage for disabled children under 19 years old based on specific income criteria. If a parent of an individual offers family coverage under a group health plan, the State may require the parent to enroll in and pay premiums for such coverage for their child to remain eligible for medical assistance. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2005" allows families to purchase Medicaid coverage for disabled children under 19 years old based on specific income criteria. States may reduce premiums for private coverage provided by parents and treat it as third party liability. States also have the option to impose income-related premiums under Section 1916. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2005" allows families to purchase Medicaid coverage for disabled children under 19 years old based on specific income criteria. States may impose income-related premiums on disabled children's families, set on a sliding scale based on family income, under Section 1916. The "Family Opportunity Act of 2005" allows families to purchase Medicaid coverage for disabled children under 19 years old based on specific income criteria. States may impose income-related premiums on disabled children's families, set on a sliding scale based on family income, under Section 1916. Premiums are capped at 5% of family income if it exceeds 100% but does not exceed 200% of the poverty line, and at 7.5% if it exceeds 200% but does not exceed 300% of the poverty line. States cannot require prepayment of premiums or terminate eligibility based on non-payment. The amendment allows states to waive premiums for disabled children under Medicaid if payment would cause undue hardship. Conforming amendments are made to sections 1903(f)(4) and 1905(u)(2)(B). The effective date of these changes is specified. The amendments made by this section apply to medical assistance for items and services furnished on or after October 1, 2005. Demonstration projects for home and community-based alternatives to psychiatric residential treatment facilities for children are outlined in Section 4. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is authorized to conduct demonstration projects in up to 10 States to test the effectiveness of providing home and community-based alternatives to psychiatric residential treatment for children enrolled in the Medicaid program. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can conduct demonstration projects in 10 States to test home and community-based alternatives for children in Medicaid. Psychiatric residential treatment facilities are considered under the Social Security Act, and States can choose to continue Medicaid coverage for children after project termination. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can conduct demonstration projects in 10 States to test home and community-based alternatives for children in Medicaid, in accordance with section 1915(c) of the Social Security Act. Expenditures for medical assistance will be treated as a home and community-based waiver program for payment purposes. Demonstration projects will be subject to the same terms and conditions as a waiver under section 1915(c) of the Social Security Act. The Secretary must ensure budget neutrality for demonstration projects under section 1915(c) of the Social Security Act. Evaluation of the projects must include independent third-party assessments and reports to the Secretary. The Secretary must report to the President and Congress on the evaluation of State demonstration projects under this section, with limitations on funding and scope. The Secretary will report to the President and Congress on the evaluations of State demonstration projects within 12 months. $218,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal years 2006 through 2010, with $1,000,000 allocated for the Secretary's evaluations and report. The amount specified in this paragraph for fiscal years 2006 to 2010 is determined by adding the specified amounts for each fiscal year as outlined in subparagraph (B). SEC. 5. DEVELOPMENT AND SUPPORT OF FAMILY-TO-FAMILY HEALTH INFORMATION CENTERS. Section 501 (42 U.S.C. 701) is amended to provide funding for family-to-family health information centers. $3,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal year 2006, $4,000,000 for fiscal year 2007, and $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2008. Additionally, $5,000,000 is authorized for each of fiscal years 2009 and 2010. Family-to-family health information centers are funded under Section 501, with specific appropriations for fiscal years 2006 to 2008 and authorized amounts for 2009 and 2010. These centers assist families of children with disabilities or special health care needs in making informed health care choices, providing information on resources, successful health delivery models, and promoting good treatment decisions. Family-to-family health information centers, funded under Section 501, assist families of children with disabilities or special health care needs by developing collaboration models, providing training, conducting outreach activities, and being staffed by families with expertise in healthcare systems and health professionals. The Secretary is responsible for developing these centers in accordance with specific guidelines. In accordance with specific guidelines, family-to-family health information centers will be developed in at least 25 states in fiscal year 2006, 40 states in fiscal year 2007, and all states in fiscal year 2008. The provisions applicable to the funds for the Secretary under section 502(a)(1) also apply to funds under paragraph (1)(A). The term 'State' refers to each of the 50 states and the District of Columbia. SEC. 6. RESTORATION OF MEDICAID ELIGIBILITY FOR CERTAIN SSI BENEFICIARIES. Amends Section 1902(a)(10)(A)(i)(II) to include individuals under 21 years old eligible for Medicaid if they would receive supplemental security income benefits under title XVI. Effective from January 1, 2006, for medical assistance.
